evidence_span: In the third pass of zirconium tube pilgering that we studied here, a material element will go through a series of about 100 strokes as it travels from entry to exit of the mandrel.

evidence_span: Each stroke imposes only a very small strain, $\Delta \overline { { \epsilon } } \approx 0 . 0 2$ or 0.03.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: From the similarity between the mandrel displacement and force evolution, the stiffness of the mandrel-mandrel rod system can be determined to be $3 0 0 0 ~ \mathrm { N / m m }$ during the forward stroke.

evidence_span: It is smaller during the return stroke (1500 $\mathbf { N } / \mathbf { m m } )$ due to elastic buckling and bending of the mandrel rod.

evidence_span: Comparing the preform displacement and force, the preform/carriage stiffness is found to be $2 5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { N / m m }$ during the forward stroke

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk2
evidence_span: and $3 0 0 0 \mathrm { N / m m }$ for the return stroke.

evidence_span: comparing gap and roll force curves, measured for several rolling conditions and tools, a stand stiffness of $7 . 4 ~ 1 0 ^ { 5 } ~ \mathrm { N / m m }$ has been deduced.

evidence_span: A numerical approach by the FEM (code FORGE2), in a simplified, axisymmetric geometry, has shown that the incremental strain, $\Delta \epsilon _ { r z } ,$ is proportional to the elongational strain increment, $\Delta \epsilon _ { z s }$ and also depends on the friction coefficients (internal and external) and the sliding factor that are determined by tool design.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Welding produces local residual tensile stresses and changes in texture in components made from zirconium alloys.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Welding produces local residual tensile stresses and changes in texture in components made from zirconium alloys.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: In the heat-affected zone in tubes or plates, the basal plane normals are rotated into the plane of the component and perpendicular to the direction of the weld.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Thin-walled Zircaloy-2 tubes containing an axial weld do not reach their full strength because they always fail prematurely in the weld when pressurized to failure in a fixed-end burst test.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Reinforcing the weld by increasing its thickness by $25 \%$ moves the failure to the parent metal and improves the biaxial strength of the tube by 20 to $25 \%$ and increases the total elongation by 200 to $450 \%$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Reinforcing the weld by increasing its thickness by $25 \%$ moves the failure to the parent metal and improves the biaxial strength of the tube by 20 to $25 \%$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Reinforcing the weld by increasing its thickness by $25 \%$ moves the failure to the parent metal ... increases the total elongation by 200 to $450 \%$ .

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: In components made from $\mathbf { Z } _ { \mathbf { I } - 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b } }$ , the texture in the heat-affected zone promotes delayed hydride cracking (DHC) driven by tensile residual stress.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: Although the texture is not much affected by heat-treatments below $6 3 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: macro-residual tensile stresses can be relieved by heat treatment to the point where the probability of cracking is very low.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_017_chunk6
evidence_span: macro-residual tensile stresses can be relieved by heat treatment to the point where the probability of cracking is very low.

evidence_span: Welding zirconium produces residual stresses and local changes in microstructure and crystallographic texture.
